avalancheActivity.comment:
A lot of new snow above approximately 2200 m. This applies especially until the early morning.
Avalanches can be released very easily and reach dangerously large size. Exposed buildings and exposed parts of transportation routes are endangered over a wide area in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation.
In the regions exposed to heavier precipitation moist avalanches can penetrate even deep layers and can reach as far as low altitudes.
The conditions are treacherous for backcountry touring.
avalancheActivity.highlights: The large quantity of fresh snow as well as the often large wind slabs will become increasingly prone to triggering. As the snowfall becomes more intense numerous moist and wet avalanches are to be expected at any time, but they can be dangerously large.

snowpackStructure.comment:
The sleet will give rise to a loss of strength within the snowpack over a wide area in particular in all altitude zones.
As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind, large wind slabs formed in particular in gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain as well as at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions.
Over a wide area 70 to 100 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until late morning above approximately 2300 m.

tendency.comment: The peak danger point will be reached during the night.

avalancheActivity.comment:
From high-altitude starting zones in particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation the avalanches can reach large size and in some places endanger transportation routes, including those situated at relatively low altitudes. This applies especially in the regions with a lot of snow.
Increase in danger of moist and wet avalanches until the temperature drops.
The conditions are very critical for ski touring, freeriding and snowshoe hiking.
avalancheActivity.highlights: Gradual decrease in avalanche danger as the snowfall eases. Avalanches can reach valley bottoms and endanger exposed transportation routes.

snowpackStructure.comment:
Up to intermediate altitudes rain will fall over a wide area. A lot of new snow in the high Alpine regions. As a consequence of new snow and wind, sometimes large wind slabs formed in the last few days.
The sleet will give rise to a loss of strength within the snowpack over a wide area in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.
Over a wide area 50 to 80 cm of snow will fall until late morning above approximately 2300 m.

avalancheActivity.comment:
A lot of new snow above approximately 2200 m. This applies until the early morning.
Avalanches can be released very easily and reach dangerously large size. Exposed buildings and exposed parts of transportation routes are endangered in some cases in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation.
Below approximately 2200 m moist and wet avalanches are possible. In particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation moist avalanches can penetrate even deep layers.
The conditions are very dangerous for backcountry touring and snowshoe hiking.
avalancheActivity.highlights: The large quantity of fresh snow as well as the often large wind slabs will become increasingly prone to triggering. Numerous dry and wet avalanches are to be expected at any time, but they can be dangerously large.

snowpackStructure.comment:
The sleet will give rise to a loss of strength within the snowpack over a wide area in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.
As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind, large wind slabs formed in particular in gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain as well as at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions.
Over a wide area 30 to 60 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until late morning above approximately 2300 m.

tendency.comment: The peak danger point will be reached by the early morning.

avalancheActivity.comment:
As the snowfall eases the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent by the early morning.
As the penetration by moisture increases more frequent wet avalanches are possible as the day progresses below approximately 2200 m.
The more recent wind slabs will be covered with new snow and therefore difficult to recognise. New snow and wind slabs can in some places be released easily and reach large size.
The current avalanche situation calls for great caution and restraint.
avalancheActivity.highlights: Gradual decrease in avalanche danger as a consequence of the ceasing of precipitation.

snowpackStructure.comment:
Up to intermediate altitudes rain will fall over a wide area. The sleet will give rise to a loss of strength within the snowpack over a wide area in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.
As a consequence of new snow and wind, sometimes large wind slabs formed in the last few days in particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. Over a wide area 20 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until late morning above approximately 2300 m.
